title: Best SSDs of 2024: Reviews and buying advice
description:
Switching to a solid-state drive is the best upgrade you can make for your PC. These wondrous devices speed up boot times, improve the responsiveness of your programs and games, and generally make your computer feel fast. But not all solid-state drives are the same. You can spend big to achieve read and write speeds that reach a whole other level, or you can find top-notch SSDs that offer solid performance without breaking the bank.

Many SSDs come in a 2.5-inch form factor and connect to your PC via the same SATA port used by a traditional hard drive. But tiny NVMe (Non-Volatile Memory Express) “gumstick” SSDs that fit in an M.2 connection on a modern motherboard are becoming increasin

title: Are backside motherboard connections really the future?
description:
We’ve been hearing a lot about a huge shift in the way custom PCs are made from the last two years of CES, something we at PCWorld have dubbed “the War on Cables.” But despite a few promising products hitting the market, this would-be revolution still seems very much in the incipient stage. Is this shift in the market really going to happen or will it be a mega-sized flop? On the show floor at CES 2024, Adam is joined by KitGuru’s Senior Technical Writer and ATX Hater, Leo Waldock, to hash it out.

There are now three technically competing, but broadly very similar, implementations of this idea going at once:

title: This 75-inch, $630 Hisense TV is ready for the big game
description:
If you’re looking to pick up a new TV for the upcoming Superbowl, you’ve come to the right place. Amazon’s selling the Hisense 75U6HF Smart TV for just $629.99, which is a colossal savings of $520. This TV measures 75-inches as well as a maximum brightness of 600 nits. Did I also mention the 4K resolution? If you’re after the ultimate Superbowl-watching experience, this TV really has it all. Let’s dive right into the details then.

The Hisense features the aforementioned 4K resolution, a 240Hz motion rate, and up to 220 local dimming zones. Based on those numbers, visuals should be nice and smooth. It’s also compatible with Alexa an

title: Best HDMI cables for monitors: The differences matter
description:
Buying an HDMI cable should be simple—but some cables don’t perform as expected, while others don’t clearly indicate the HDMI specifications supported.

If you don’t have time to dig into the details yourself, use this guide to grab the right cable for your needs. We’ve sorted it by HDMI specification (also known as HDMI version), so you can find an instant, affordable match. Our picks also sidestep the problems you might encounter when hunting on your own, be it cheaply made cables that perform poorly or overpriced ones that do nothing better than less expensive alternatives.

Need a cable to use with a high-refresh monitor, especially one above 144Hz? We generally recommend using a DisplayPort cable instead of HDMI—look for one rated for DisplayPort 1.3 or higher.

title: Give your Valentine a Microsoft Office upgrade for just $30
description:

It’s not exactly steamy, but the gift of Microsoft Office says you know what your partner needs. And since you can get the 2019 version for either Windows or Mac for just $29.97 for a limited time, why not take advantage?

title: Xbox Game Pass Ultimate tip: Get 2 years of access for dirt cheap
description:
For over four years, gamers have been able to access hundreds of titles across PC and Xbox via Microsoft’s Xbox Game Pass Ultimate subscription service—but you don’t have to pay full price. With a few smart moves, you can lock in a 52 percent discount on Xbox Game Pass Ultimate for up to two years.
